8E717982946D41C6BD5F3074180E77A1.description: Define problems caused by the introduction of a new species in an environment and design devices or solutions to minimize the impact(s) to the balance of an ecosystem.

20177B755CAA409A9CD270E6B91C08DD.description: Analyze and interpret data to predict how changes in the number of organisms of one species affects the balance of an ecosystem.

78976D98C1FB4C9592E0DCC91F4CEDCB.description: Develop and use models (food webs and energy pyramids) to exemplify how the transfer of energy in an ecosystem supports the concept that energy is conserved.

E29F1C2AF997415B99100F706EDF9977.description:
Develop and use models to explain how organisms interact in a competitive or
mutually beneficial relationship for food, shelter, or space (including competition,
mutualism, commensalism, parasitism, and predator-prey relationships).

3CE4B347683A4582819CF5F114DB7117.description:
Organisms in all ecosystems interact with and depend upon
each other. Organisms with similar needs compete for limited resources. Food webs and energy
pyramids are models that demonstrate how energy is transferred within an ecosystem.

63206D050C184AEBBB07C3F825CA5974.description: 7.EC.5A.3 Analyze and interpret data to predict changes in the number of organisms within a population when certain changes occur to the physical environment (such as changes due to natural hazards or limiting factors).

44C863C6B2D64E0E92A04A6AE51D667B.description: Construct explanations of how soil quality (including composition, texture, particle size, permeability, and pH) affects the characteristics of an ecosystem using evidence from soil profiles.

CC75FF1E69AB4FEAAE15E18AE2552B2F.description:
Develop and use models to describe the characteristics of the levels of organization
within ecosystems (including species, populations, communities, ecosystems, and
biomes).

6638C6463C21453587D63B77A74A68B6.description:
In all ecosystems, organisms and populations of organisms
depend on their environmental interactions with other living things (biotic factors) and with
physical (abiotic) factors (such as light, temperature, water, or soil quality). Disruptions to any
component of an ecosystem can lead to shifts in its diversity and abundance of populations.

DF59277C83BC4CF493DFE9FE57C3C80C.description:
ECOLOGY: INTERACTIONS OF LIVING SYSTEMS AND THE ENVIRONMENT:  The student will demonstrate an understanding of how organisms interact with
and respond to the biotic and abiotic components of their environments.

374E9BB06DB046AA99BAD72DAF1B871A.description: 7.L.4A.6 Construct scientific arguments using evidence to support claims concerning the advantages and disadvantages of the use of technology (such as selective breeding, genetic engineering, or biomedical research) in influencing the transfer of genetic information.

FD4A9EC0F0514330B06DC0C8A78126DE.description: Construct scientific arguments using evidence to support claims for how changes in genes (mutations) may have beneficial, harmful, or neutral effects on organisms.

EEB0E5CFF4BE4DE9B6B6BD63DBAF53F3.description: Use mathematical and computational thinking to predict the probability of phenotypes and genotypes based on patterns of inheritance.

6846C856A4D543D1934F2F64FCF90D2E.description: Develop and use models (Punnett squares) to describe and predict patterns of the inheritance of single genetic traits from parent to offspring (including dominant and recessive traits, incomplete dominance, and codominance).

21F3F1DF239548928BFC185C1327FFC4.description: Construct explanations for how genetic information is transferred from parent to offspring in organisms that reproduce sexually.

C12A66028CA846E7BF5C144C2AADC5F7.description:
Obtain and communicate information about the relationship between genes and
chromosomes to construct explanations of their relationship to inherited characteristics.

F31F96C0D95342299BF875544FD8DA2C.description:
Inheritance is the key process causing similarities between
parental organisms and their offspring. Organisms that reproduce sexually transfer genetic
information (DNA) to their offspring. This transfer of genetic information through inheritance
leads to greater similarity among individuals within a population than between populations.
Technology allows humans to influence the transfer of genetic information.

2C1FF2972BAD4236AB93300CC61DC116.description:
LIFE SCIENCE: HEREDITY – INHERITANCE AND VARIATION OF TRAITS: The student will demonstrate an understanding of how genetic information is
transferred from parent to offspring and how environmental factors and the use of technologies
influence the transfer of genetic information.

F7C090D6BECA47C7B3839F87163B4F12.description: Construct explanations for how systems in the human body (including circulatory, respiratory, digestive, excretory, nervous, and musculoskeletal systems) work together to support the essential life functions of the body.

121F13A52FC245C8A61F8BB6FCFB12D9.description:
Develop and use models to explain how the structural organizations within multi-cellular
organisms function to serve the needs of the organism.

213CDE6A00D949E09CBA788FBC82D59F.description:
Multi-cellular organisms (including humans) are complex
systems with specialized cells that perform specific functions. Organs and organ systems are
composed of cells that function to serve the needs of cells which in turn serve the needs of the
organism.

9057F919929D48E2BF96FBFA93DD42F2.description: Construct scientific arguments to support claims that bacteria are both helpful and harmful to other organisms and the environment.

6CFD1467CB4D4FBABFD2C410E6001D9E.description: Develop and use models to explain how the relevant structures within cells (including cytoplasm, cell membrane, cell wall, nucleus, mitochondria, chloroplasts, lysosomes, and vacuoles) function to support the life of plant, animal, and bacterial cells.

75789960CFCB4C66851D21F212FD195F.description: Analyze and interpret data from observations to describe different types of cells and classify cells as plant, animal, protist, or bacteria.

E83536FFD17D46DFA57BD364DFA87326.description:
Obtain and communicate information to support claims that (1) organisms are made of
one or more cells, (2) cells are the basic unit of structure and function of organisms, and
(3) cells come only from existing cells.

DCA00CBAFD244805ABC6443C2B4F6F27.description:
Cells are the most basic unit of any living organism. All
organisms are composed of one (unicellular) or many cells (multi-cellular) and require food and
water, a way to dispose of waste, and an environment in which they can live in order to survive.
Through the use of technology, scientists have discovered special structures within individual cells
that have specific functions that allow the cell to grow, survive, and reproduce. Bacteria are one-celled organisms found almost everywhere and can be both helpful and harmful. They can be
simply classified by their size, shape and whether or not they can move.

17C3551DBF6D4E7BAC63397F279169B9.description:
LIFE SCIENCE: ORGANIZATION IN LIVING SYSTEMS:  The student will demonstrate an understanding of how the levels of organization
within organisms support the essential functions of life.

C24FE6D39FF24757BAA696E4FC61BFA6.description: Develop and use models to explain how chemical reactions are supported by the law of conservation of matter.

2C370BD62C3340B2AFD934E550231238.description: Plan and conduct controlled scientific investigations to answer questions about how physical and chemical changes affect the properties of different substances.

0162DF1424FB43A5B469D18F73878FC2.description:
Analyze and interpret data to compare the physical properties, chemical properties
(neutralization to form a salt, reaction with metals), and pH of various solutions and
classify solutions as acids or bases.

823424E962EC4B6586555FE0120ADE6A.description:
Use mathematical and computational thinking to describe the relationship between the
mass, volume, and density of a given substance.

989A78F7037D40FF8CB9973D4F78ED90.description:
Analyze and interpret data to describe substances using physical properties (including
state, boiling/melting point, density, conductivity, color, hardness, and magnetic
properties) and chemical properties (the ability to burn or rust).

33569CA3F9134E85AABD59B16C64A1EF.description:
Substances (such as metals or acids) are identified according
to their physical or chemical properties. Changes to substances can either be physical or chemical.
Many substances react chemically with other substances to form new substances with different
properties. According to the law of conservation of matter, total mass does not change in a chemical
reaction.

2AE81030FBEE4BAC8F3600DE537E86D5.description:
Construct explanations for how compounds are classified as ionic (metal bonded to
nonmetal) or covalent (nonmetals bonded together) using chemical formulas.

EB2B76BF9902451883652551BF7CFCC2.description:
Analyze and interpret data to describe and classify matter as pure substances (elements
or compounds) or mixtures (heterogeneous or homogeneous) based on composition.

B37170E04BF44656B97DF6B299FFE662.description:
Obtain and use information about elements (including chemical symbol, atomic number,
atomic mass, and group or family) to describe the organization of the periodic table.

94347C6012144AEFB9308F7A68C0E142.description:
Develop and use simple atomic models to illustrate the components of elements
(including the relative position and charge of protons, neutrons, and electrons).

D86504C71B2A4CED8F8C0803A7CBCFF9.description:
All substances are composed of one or more elements.
Elements are pure substances which contain only one kind of atom. The periodic table organizes
these elements based on similar properties. Compounds are substances composed of two or more
elements. Chemical formulas can be used to describe compounds.

8CB5DD747D764029B095C70684363D2F.description:
PHYSICAL SCIENCE: CLASSIFICATION AND CONSERVATION OF MATTER:  The student will demonstrate an understanding of the structure and properties of
matter and that matter is conserved as it undergoes changes.
